I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan for the additional financing of the Panj–Amu River Basin 
Sector Project.1 
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the original project on 26 October 2016.2 
The project was designed to increase agricultural productivity in the Panj–Amu River Basin in 
northeast Afghanistan by improving access to and use of water and building climate resilience 
through the implementation of watershed natural resource management plans. The project’s 
impact is per capita income increased and poverty among rural and pastoral communities 
reduced. The current project has three outputs (para. 7). The additional financing will expand the 
scope of output 3 to include additional watershed subprojects. Panj–Amu River Basin is a major 
production center for wheat, rice, vegetables, and fruit. Subproject investments will target water 
harvesting to increase water availability by increasing underground water recharge, improving 
access, and reducing water runoff and flood damage. The report and recommendation of the 
President for the ongoing project is accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The proposed project meets the eligibility criteria for additional financing. The original 
project’s rating is on-track. The project outcomes will be achieved by the original project’s closing 
date of 31 May 2023. Physical progress was about 47%3 as of 31 August 2020 (elapsed time: 
55%).  Cumulative  contract  awards  were  $42.31  million  (57%)  while  disbursements  were 
$13.76 million (18%). Outputs 2 and 3 of the original project are progressing well. Output 1 initial 
delays were rectified. The original project complies with fiduciary requirements, environmental 
and social safeguard policies, and is successful in risk management. The midterm review found 
no issues with grant covenant compliance, except for the covenant on the preparation and 
issuance of an operation and maintenance (O&M) policy. 
 
4.  Responding to the severe climate events—namely, a large-scale drought in 2018 and 
severe floods in 2019—the government prioritized water harvesting.4 As per the national water 
harvesting program, the National Water Affairs Regulation Authority (NWARA)5 identified and 
prepared prefeasibility studies on 334 subprojects, with many being small to medium scale (8–
11,500 hectares [ha]). Given the good progress under output 3 (para. 8), the government 
requested ADB support to expand its watershed interventions in the Panj–Amu River Basin. The 
additional  financing  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for  Afghanistan, 
2017−2021. 6  It  is  included  in  ADB’s  country  operation  business  plan  for  Afghanistan, 
2020−2022.7 It also supports ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational priorities of addressing poverty 
and gender equality,  tackling climate change and building climate and disaster resilience, 
 
1  ADB. 2016. Afghanistan: Panj-Amu River Basin Sector Project. Manila. 
2  Total amount is $76 million (European Union: $50 million equivalent; Asian Development Fund: $26 million). 
3  Includes completion of soft components, award of all community development councils, consultancies, and majority 
of national competitive bidding (NCB) contracts. 
4  Presidential Decree No. 237 (2019), supported though letter No. 962/835, called for improving water retention in 
watersheds, reducing runoff, improving household access to water, and stabilizing slope land.  
5  NWARA is undertaking the water sector functions and implementation role of the dissolved Ministry of Energy and 
Water (MEW), which was one of the implementing agencies in the original project (para.17). 
6  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Afghanistan, 2017–2021. Manila.  
7  ADB. 2019. Country Operational Business Plan: Afghanistan, 2020–2022. Manila.

2 
promoting rural development and food security, and strengthening governance and institutional 
capacity.8 
 
5.  The Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) epidemic resulted in a contraction in the economy, 
with increased levels of unemployment especially in the informal sector in urban and rural areas, 
and increased poverty and food insecurity. The government is tackling the COVID-19 epidemic 
with a national COVID-19 program and targeted social welfare support.  
 
6.  This project is relevant and appropriate in the current Afghanistan COVID-19 environment, 
as it is focused on smallholder households and local communities, with activities that will generate 
improved household incomes, livelihoods and employment. The project will have a direct local 
impact with improved livelihoods, decreasing poverty and food insecurity. The employment 
generated may benefit those workers who have lost employment in off-farm activities that have 
closed due to COVID-19. The improved livelihoods will enable households to access health 
services if they are affected by COVID-19. 
 
7.  The additional financing will enhance resilience of watersheds to disaster and climate risks 
by adding 77 watershed subprojects under output 3.9 The new activities will be completed within 
the original project period ending 31 May 2023. The additional financing modality is appropriate10 
since the activities supplement activities of the original project. The original project’s sector 
modality, design, and implementation arrangements can also be used efficiently.  
 
8.  The project follows the fragile and conflict-affected situations and enhanced project 
delivery approaches and includes: (i) sector financing, which allows flexibility in subproject 
selection and implementation given security concerns; (ii) streamlined project management office 
structure,  which  helps  long-term  programmatic  sector  interventions;  and  (iii)  community 
participation  in  procurement  and  involvement  of  local  elders,  which  minimizes  interruption 
(including security) of work. The project readiness is enhanced by the advance contracting. 
 
B.  Project Description 
 
9.  The project is aligned with the following impacts: per capita income increased and poverty 
among rural and pastoral communities reduced.11 The project will have the following outcome: 
agricultural productivity in the Panj–Amu River Basin increased.12 The project outputs are (i) 
water allocation and availability improved, (ii) command areas enhanced; and (iii) watersheds 
properly managed and protected. The impact, outcome, and outputs will remain unchanged for 
the overall project.  
 
10.  Under output 3 of the original project, activities are being undertaken for 26 watershed 
subprojects in three provinces (Badakhshan, Kunduz, and Takhar). Details are provided in the 
Summary of Project Performance.13 With the additional financing, the project will expand activities 
to an additional 77 watershed subprojects in the existing three project provinces and in six 
additional provinces: Samangan, Baghlan, Bamiyan, Panjshir, Parwan, and Wardak. Forty-two of 
the  subprojects  will  involve  small  investments  (less  than  $100,000)  and  35  will  involve 
 
8  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
9  Priority Subprojects and Selection Criteria accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2. 
10 ADB. 2018. Additional Financing. Operations Manual. OM H5. Manila. 
11 Islamic Republic of Afghanistan. 2017. Afghanistan National Peace and Development Framework, 2017–2021.  
12 The revised design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
13 Summary Project Performance (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

3 
investments greater than $100,000. Subproject selection criteria is detailed in Priority Subprojects 
and Selection Criteria.14 
 
11.  The forestry and rangeland protection target under output 3 will be increased from 10,000 
ha to 27,760 ha. Activities under the additional subprojects will include (i) installation of physical 
infrastructure and application of bioengineering (revegetation and reforestation) to improve water 
availability to rural households for irrigation and other uses, increase recharge, and reduce runoff 
and  sedimentation;  and  (ii)  preparation  of  watershed  resource  management  plans,  with 
community-based organization engagement at subproject sites to be developed through water 
users  associations  (WUAs)  and  community  development  councils. 15 Staff  training  will  be 
expanded to cover the new subproject areas. Training will target river basin and sub-river basin 
authority staff, local NWARA staff, and departments of agriculture, irrigation, and livestock (DAILs) 
staff. The training will enable staff to become master trainers to train communities. 
 
12.  As a result of the change in scope to output 3, one of the project’s original outcome 
indicator targets will change: the target command area (irrigated agricultural land) for the overall 
project will expand from 74,500 ha to 146,900 ha. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
13.  ADB’s value addition is in implementing climate adaptation systems. This is based on 
watershed land improvements through flood management and improved irrigation and drainage, 
which will improve rural livelihoods (including of women) and food security and reduce poverty. 
ADB support will also target sustainable O&M systems and building government and local 
institutional capacity. The project is innovative in applying an integrated sustainable approach to 
climate change and disaster risk management in upper watersheds. Subproject interventions will 
increase access to water (e.g., water storage ponds, check dams), provide improvements to 
precipitation infiltration and recharge, and reduce soil erosion and landslides by restoring the 
original  vegetation.  Technical  packages  and  natural  resource  management  plans  will  be 
developed for each selected subproject site and adaptation measures adopted. It will build on 
ADB’s in-country extensive engagement in water resource management and rural development.16  
 
D.  Summary Cost Estimates and Financing Plans 
 
14.  The overall project is estimated to cost $95.28 million (Table 1).

15.  Detailed cost estimates by expenditure category and by financier are included in the

16.  The government has requested a grant not exceeding $18.28 million from ADB’s Special

17.  The summary financing plan is in Table 2 and is further detailed in the PAM. ADB will 
finance the expenditures in relation to civil works, non-land acquisition and resettlement costs,18 
incremental project staff, and office operation costs. ADB will also finance taxes and duties. The 
government will contribute $0.25 million in the form of office space and utilities.

18.  Climate adaptation is estimated to cost $6.4 million, of which ADB will finance 100%.19 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  The original project’s implementation arrangements will be retained. The Ministry of 
Finance (MOF) will remain the executing agency. NWARA will be the implementing agency for 
the additional subprojects and will coordinate all activities with Ministry of Agriculture, Irrigation 
and Livestock (MAIL). In 19 February 2020, NWARA replaced the Ministry of Energy and Water 
(MEW) for water projects implementation.20 This change did not impact implementing agency’s 
capacity  as  NWARA  retained  its  functions,  mandates,  and  staff.  The  NWARA’s  technical, 
procurement, financial, safeguards, gender, monitoring, and evaluation departments remain 
unchanged.  NWARA  and  the  river  basin  and  sub-river  basin  authorities  were  engaged  in 
watershed management and planning activities under the original output 3. The original project 
 
17 Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
18 Does not include the costs for land acquisition and resettlement, that will be financed by the government (if any). 
19 Climate Change Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
20 Presidential Decree No. 36 (2020) dissolved MEW and restructured it into a new agency, NWARA.

5 
developed an efficient coordination system across all project activities. The community-based 
engagement and partnership will continue with the local community organizations. The project 
implementation consultant team engaged under the original project will be funded by the original 
project and will support both projects.21 The implementation arrangements are detailed in the 
PAM. The implementation period is for 2 years, with grant closing on 31 May 2023. 
 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Summary of Due Diligence Results 
 
20.  A summary of the due diligence assessments is presented in Table 3. The full due 
diligence assessments are accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2. 
 
Table 3: Summary of Due Diligence Assessments 
Area of Assessment  Summary of Assessment 
Technical  The project classification is high climate risk.a A climate and disaster risk assessment and 
management report was prepared. All subprojects will be screened for climate and disaster 
risks  and  will  incorporate  risk-reduction measures. The additional  financing  will use 
subproject watershed designs and approaches that have proven effective under the original 
project, and are within the capacity of local community organizations.b The interventions will 
increase resilience to potential climate change impacts. They will increase water retention, 
and water access for households, irrigation and livestock uses, and water recharge. Slope 
stabilization with revegetation and reforestation will reduce soil loss and flood damage. 
Economic and  The additional financing will generate significant financial and economic benefits at the 
financial viability  watershed and household levels. The analysis of two representative subprojects indicates 
that the investments will be economically and financially viable, and directly generate 
increased levels of on-farm employment and incremental returns at the household level and 
increase off-farm rural employment. The economic internal rates of return of 14.1% and 
31.7% for the two subprojects are above the opportunity cost of capital of 9%. 
Sustainability  The local community organizations that will be implementing the subproject interventions 
(in watershed resource management planning and bioengineering) will achieve higher 
productivity and incremental returns. Higher returns and improved livelihoods provide 
incentives for farm households to adopt sustainable O&M systems, including desilting and 
sedimentation removal on an annual basis. The government will ensure that, for structures 
beyond the capacity of community-based O&M, adequate funds are allocated from the 
government’s budget to finance the O&M activities of SBAs. For community-based O&M, 
the government will ensure that pre-construction O&M agreements are signed before any 
watershed and/or irrigation works start. SBAs and WUAs will sign handover agreements 
with community development councils and other community organizations before any civil 
works are commissioned. These agreements will also cover the commitments for O&M. 
Governance  As per NWARA’s financial management assessment there are no significant risks related 
to project management. Nevertheless, the over-all pre-mitigation financial management risk 
of NWARA is substantial. NWARA project management offices are experienced with ADB 
projects. Under the original project, audited financial statements are timely submitted as per 
the auditing standards acceptable to ADB, and internal audit reports are submitted annually 
to ADB. The procurement risk classification is assessed as substantial; procurement 
specialists and staff under the original project will be engaged to enhance IA’s procurement 
capacity. All procurement and recruitment of consultants under the ADB grant will be carried 
out in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time), 
Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time), and 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). ADB’s 
Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to the MOF and NWARA. 
Poverty, social, and  The national poverty rate in 2016–2017 was 54.5%. In the core project regions in the north 
gender  and northeast the poverty rate was higher (57.9% in the north and 62.8% in the northeast).c 
Similarly, the rate of severe food insecurity in these regions exceeds the national rate of 
45%. The project’s watershed subprojects will reduce poverty and food insecurity for low-
 
21 A technical assistant is programmed in late 2020, that aims to contribute to strengthening the capacity of government 
in improving sustainable infrastructure development in the sector.

6 
income and marginal smallholders, pastoralists, and communities by creating jobs and 
improving  water access,  agricultural  productivity  and  incomes,  livelihoods,  and  food 
security.d These interventions will also be important to support communities in mitigating 
and recovering from the COVID-19 epidemic. The project is categorized effective gender 
mainstreaming. NWARA and MAIL will actively engage rural women in the community-
based organizations through community contracting and training courses. This will further 
improve women’s participation in irrigation associations. The additional financing will now 
involve women in managing watershed resources and creating livelihoods from nursery and 
forest resource management. The women are active participants in several watershed 
activities such as community mobilization and watershed management planning. 
Safeguards  Environment (category B). An environmental assessment and review framework was 
prepared to ensure project compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). It 
was disclosed on the ADB website in July 2020. Adequate resources are allocated for 
environmental safeguards preparation, implementation, monitoring, and reporting.  
Indigenous peoples (category C). There are no indigenous peoples identified in project 
site areas as defined in ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement for operational purposes. 
Involuntary resettlement (category B). The original project LARF was updated to guide 
the preparation of subproject LARPs. Due diligence will be conducted in areas where no 
LAR impacts are anticipated. Upon due diligence completion and confirmation of no LAR 
impact, a due diligence report will be prepared and disclosed upon ADB’s acceptance. LAR 
plans will be prepared for LAR-impacted areas, accepted by ADB and disclosed prior to 
award of contract, with implementation prior to civil works commencement. Consultations 
with the affected communities will be ongoing at all stages. ADB will recruit a TPM firm to 
monitor project implementation to enhance portfolio monitoring and reporting.  
ADB = Asian Development Bank, LAR = land acquisition and resettlement, NWARA = National Water Affairs Regulation 
Authority, O&M = operation and maintenance, SBA = sub-river basin authority, WUA = water users association. 
a  Climate Change Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
b  42 of the 77 subprojects will involve community-based contracting. Subprojects range from $15,000 to $90,000. 
c  Central Statistics Organization. 2018. Afghanistan Living Conditions Survey 2016–2017. Kabul. 
d  Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
21.  The many small-scale activities across several watersheds provides flexibility to respond 
to COVID-19 and future outbreaks, as there is the flexibility to focus activities to other project 
areas. Local communities will be trained in COVID -19 work practices during construction. The 
additional activities will be implemented on time and within budget. 
 
B.  Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
22.  Significant risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in 
detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.22 
 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigation Measures 
Insecurity delays or suspends field  A participatory community-based approach will ensure strong community 
activities  ownership. National contractors will be responsible for their staff security. 
Insufficient available funds for O&M may  O&M costs will be covered by irrigation service fee and stipulated in 
jeopardize infrastructure sustainability  subproject  irrigation  management  and  transfer  agreements,  and  in 
watershed  management  agreements  with  local  communities.  For 
Subproject works outside communities’ scope, government funds will be 
included in annual budget. 
Consolidated government financial  Existing project management office at NWARA is staffed with personnel 
statements deviate from international  experienced in preparing project cash-basis financial statements. 
accounting standards 
Adverse climate effects on production  All subprojects will be screened for climate and disaster risks, and will 
and productivity  incorporate risk-reduction measures in the designs to improve watershed 
management through physical and bioengineering interventions. 
 
22 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

7 
Risks  Mitigation Measures 
Widespread corruption in public sector  Align implementation of the anticorruption strategy through the High Office 
and poor governance  of Oversight and Anticorruption. The project financial management system 
was designed to encourage accountability and minimize risks, and includes 
project implementation unit requirement for the review of primary payment 
documentation supporting expenditures before endorsing payments. 
Non transparency and integrity violations  Requirement in place for prior agreement with ADB on (i) bidder’s selection 
in procurement and in awarding contracts  criteria for construction of check dams; (ii) review of evaluation reports (ERs) 
to civil works contractors    for first five CPP packages; and (ii) review of bid evaluation reports (BERs) 
of all NCB  packages to ensure transparency and competitiveness. 
NWARA = National Water Affairs Regulation Authority, O&M = operation and maintenance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
23.  The government and MOF have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB requirements, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, financial management, and disbursement 
as described in detail in the PAM and in the grant document. The government and MOF have 
agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the grant agreement. 
 
24.  Operation and maintenance. The government will ensure that, for structures outside the 
capacity of community-based O&M, adequate funds are allocated from the government’s budget 
to finance the O&M activities of sub-basin authorities (SBAs). This will include funds for the 
efficient  operation  of  sluice  gates  in  larger  structures.  For  community-based  O&M,  the 
government will ensure that pre-construction O&M agreements are signed before starting any 
watershed  and/or  irrigation  works.  SBAs  and  WUAs  will  sign  handover  agreements  with 
community development councils and other community organizations before any civil works are 
commissioned. These agreements will also cover the commitments for O&M of check dams, 
including desilting and sedimentation removal. These will also be applicable for WUAs and the 
O&M and cleaning of offtakes. For other watershed management planning and bioengineering 
works,  such  agreements  will  be  signed  between  the  SBAs  and  the  respective  community 
organizations to ensure long-term watershed sustainability. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
25.  I am satisfied that the proposed grant would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the grant not exceeding 
$18,280,000 to the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan from ADB’s Special Funds resources (Asian 
Development Fund), for the additional financing of the Panj–Amu River Basin Sector Project, on 
terms and conditions that are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft grant 
agreement presented to the Board. 
 
 
Masatsugu Asakawa 
President 
6 October 2020

Key Activities with Milestones1 
1.  Water allocation and availability improved 
1.1 Commence construction of three representative subprojects by Q2 2017 (completed) 
1.2 Conduct feasibility and detailed design studies for other subprojects by Q3 2017 (unchanged/ongoing) 
1.3 Commence construction for other subprojects by Q4 2017 (unchanged/ongoing) 
1.4 Establish river basin model and put in use by Q3 2019 (unchanged/ongoing) 
1.5 Commission and hand over all works completed to WUAs or SBAs by Q4 2022 (unchanged) 
2.  Command areas enhanced 
2.1 Tender designed works by Q1 2018 (unchanged/ongoing) 
2.2 Train DAIL staff to become trainers by Q4 2017 (completed) 
2.3 Establish approximately 21 crop production demonstrations by Q2 2018 (unchanged/ongoing) 
2.4 Commission and hand over all works completed to irrigation associations by Q4 2022 (unchanged) 
3.  Watersheds properly managed and protected 
3.1 Identify watersheds in the vicinity of subprojects by Q4 2017 (unchanged/ongoing) 
3.2 Prepare community-based NRM technical manual and guidebook by Q1 2018 (unchanged/ongoing) 
3.3 Prepare 21 NRM plans (plus one pilot payments for ecosystem services plan) by Q2 2018 (unchanged/ 
ongoing) 
3.4 Assist 21 catchment management associations in consultation, establishment, and registration by Q3 2018 
(unchanged/ ongoing)  
3.5 Complete restoration and/or protection of selected watersheds by Q4 2022 (unchanged) 
3.6 Conduct assessments and feasibility and detailed design studies (when required) on the 77 prioritized 
watershed subprojects by Q3 2020 (added) 
3.7 Commence implementation of subproject bioengineering and physical interventions by Q1 2021 (added) 
 
1 There are several packages/actions under each activity, started in 2017 and 2018 and will continue till 2022.

Appendix 1  11 
Key Activities with Milestones1 
3.8 Prepare community-based watershed resource management plans in each of the subproject watersheds by 
Q2 2021 (added) 
3.9 Assist community-based organizations (WUAs, community development councils, irrigation associations, and 
forest management associations) to work with SBAs and DAIL in developing sustainable community watershed 
resource management systems by Q4 2021 (added) 
 
Inputs 
Asian Development Bank:  $26 million (grant) (current) 
        $18.28 million (grant) (additional) 
European Union:    $50 million (grant) (current) 
Government of Afghanistan:  $750,000 (current) 
        $250,000 (additional) 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not applicable 
DAIL = Department of Agriculture, Irrigation, and Livestock, ha = hectare, MAIL = Ministry of Agriculture, Irrigation, and 
Livestock, NRM = natural resources management, NWARA = National Water Affairs Regulation Authority, O&M = 
operation and maintenance, OP = operation priority, PPMS = project performance monitoring system, Q = quarter, SBA 
= sub-basin authority, WUA = water users association. 
a  Government of Afghanistan, 2017. Afghanistan National Peace and Development Framework, 2017–2021. Kabul.

OP 3.2.1   Area with reduced flood risk (hectares). Target: 27,760 hectares. 
OP 3.2.2    Gender-inclusive climate and disaster resilience capacity development initiatives implemented 
(number). Target: 2 nursery and forest management skills training, and 10 watershed management 
and planning programs conducted. 
OP 3.2.4  National  and  subnational  disaster  risk  reduction  and/or  management  plans  supported  in 
implementation (number). Target: 98 NRM plans. 
OP 3.2.5  New and existing infrastructure assets made climate and disaster resilient (number). Target: 103 
watershed subprojects. 
OP 5.1.1   Rural infrastructure assets established or improved (number). Target: In 21 irrigation schemes 
headworks, and main, secondary, and tertiary canals rehabilitated and upgraded.  
OP 5.3.1  Land  improved  through  climate-resilient  irrigation  infrastructure  and  water  delivery  services 
(hectares). Target: 146,900 hectares. 
OP 5.3.2  Farmers using quality farm inputs and sustainable mechanization (number). Target: Through 21 field 
demonstrations 6,300 farmers.

Updated in consultation with OGC and OCO to (i) reflect the revised ADF lending terms for group B countries, (ii) provide guidance on the waiver of member country procurement eligibility restrictions, (iii) revise the design and monitoring framework for additional financing,  and (iv) reflect OM E1 (Financing Partnerships) revised on 7 January 2013 .

metadata.Keywords: afghanistan, panj–amu river, climate resilience, access to water, water resources management, watersheds, natural water harvesting, 48042-002, adb projects, terms and conditions, board approval, rrp, approved projects, recommendations of the president
metadata.Subject: The additional financing will expand the scope of output 3 to include additional watershed subprojects. Panj–Amu River Basin is a major production center for wheat, rice, vegetables, and fruit. Subproject investments will target water harvesting to increase water availability by increasing underground water recharge, improving access, and reducing water runoff and flood damage.The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.This document dated {August 2019} is provided for the ADB project 48042-002 in Afghanistan.
metadata.Title: Panj-Amu River Basin Sector Project - Additional Financing: Report and Recommendation of the President
